Posts.Content: Hi Lynnyk! I was diagnosed a couple of months ago with triple negative lump. Primary tumour thankfully and clear nodes. I also was scared. I had cervical cancer in Austria in 2004 and had a dreadful time & was really worried this would be the same. Well, I 've now just had my second FECT-T and I just want to reassure you that although it's hard, you will get through. My Oncology Care Centre have been fabulous and there's loads of support so don't hesitate to reach out to whoever is there. You've started the process by coming on here and although you'll read some sad words from some very ill people, there is just so much positivity around. Tell your loved ones and friends exactly how you feel, and don't try to be a hero.. It's nice to be Superwoman but now is the time for you, so make use of all the help that is out there - please don't ever feel alone. Don't know if I've helped but I hope so, if even only a little bit. ((Hugs)) xx
Posts.Title: Pre-op Assessment

Posts.Content: The stuff from the hospital is called chlorhexidine gluconate antiseptic mouthwash and the one from Boots is called Boots Expert. They have the same ingredients. It stings like hell, but really works! Xxx
Posts.Title: numbness on chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne. I've been reading a lot about Citralopram recently. I'm only on 10mg a day for anxiety and I'm going to take it until the summer holidays (I work in a school) and then I'm going to taper off the dose. You don't say what dosage you're on, but Citralopram can affect libido. I agree with Barbara that there is a lot more to marriage than sex. Your husband sounds like a lovely, understanding man so please don't beat yourself up about something that you really don't have any control over. Being comfortable with each other is the most important thing right now to help you adjust to your new life post cancer. Be kind to yourself - we all set ourselves such unrealistic targets and then feel like a failure when we can't reach them. It'll happen when it's right for you but don't beat yourself up about it in the meantime, it just adds to your anxiety. Hope you feel better about yourself soon. ((Hugs)) xx
Posts.Title: I need to ask a very personal question?

Posts.Content: Hi Emma! I got peripheral neuropathy when on Docetaxal - my toes and the tips of my fingers got pins & needles and then got numb. This is a fairly common side effect. It was worse after my second cycle and my Oncologist reduced the final dose by 20% which really helped. After the third cycle my toes just twitched, I didn't get the numbness. Be sure to mention it to your Oncologist at your next appt. I didn't get any problems with my mouth as I asked for the hospital issue mouthwash that I'd had for FEC and this kept everything at bay. The chemo nurse told me I didn't need it for tax, but I'd read on here that other people had had problems so I'm glad that I insisted. You can buy mouthwash from Boots with the chlorhexidine gluconate in it and it is good too. Hope this helps - take care! Xxx
Posts.Title: numbness on chemo

Posts.Content: The waiting time for results was, for me, the worst part of my whole experience this time around ith Cancer. I was told it would be four weeks between WLE and SNB and results and I couldn't imagine how I was going to get through it. I had sailed through chemo, but this really brought me up short. You're not so mobile at the moment which makes it more difficult. A friend and I made a list of achievable tasks that I could do - just things like cleaning jewellery (didn't take long!), updating address book and birthday book, sorting out family photos, making a physical photo album from my favourite photos from phone/ computer etc. I did a lot of tidying cupboards etc. it didn't really matter what it was as long as it was achievable in a relatively short time. I spent a lot of time messaging friends on Facebook (God, they must have been fed up with my moaning!) Family and friends were a huge help. I also did a lot of walking. It's a three mile round trip to our local garden centre so my husband and I used to walk up there, have a cup of tea and then walk home. The walking was brilliant as it gets your body going and makes you tired to sleep at night. I too played games. I'm not keen on the candy crush type so I did Hay Day and You can spend a lot of time farming! I played solitaire and Free Cell and also did the scrabble type game Words with friends  my iPad was the single most useful gadget during my treatment - I think I'd have gone bonkers without it. When you get the drain out and your exercises get easier and you're more mobile you may find that some of you concentration comes back and you can read again. You don't say how long they told you it would be before you get your results  just keep posting on here and people will come up with suggestions of things they found useful and you'll find your own path. Wishing you well and ((hugs))..xxxx
Posts.Title: anxiety between mastectomy and lymph results

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa! I've just finished 3 FEC and 3 Tax. The two things I found indispensable were my iPad (for keeping in touch with the world & playing silly game) and non foaming toothpaste. I gag normally when brushing my teeth & the non foaming stuff was a godsend. I used Weleda organic stuff which a friend in Germany sent to me but I'm sure there must be an equivalent here. I think some of the smoker's toothpaste might be non foaming. It really did help! You seem to be getting well prepared & I hope you get through it with the minimum of problems. Good Luck & best wishes. Xx
Posts.Title: Shopping list for chemo - am I missing anything?

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa! I've just finished 3 FEC and 3 Tax. The two things I found indispensable were my iPad (for keeping in touch with the world & playing silly game) and non foaming toothpaste. I gag normally when brushing my teeth & the non foaming stuff was a godsend. I used Weleda organic stuff which a friend in Germany sent to me but I'm sure there must be an equivalent here. I think some of the smoker's toothpaste might be non foaming. It really did help! You seem to be getting well prepared & I hope you get through it with the minimum of problems. Good Luck & best wishes. Xx
Posts.Title: Shopping list for chemo - am I missing anything?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone! I finished my treatment on 31st December - chemotherapy, two WLES and radiotherapy. I though it might be time to cut down on the medication   I take 10mg citalopram once a day and 3 x 2mg diazepam daily. Last week I took the Citropram every other day and when I saw my GP on Monday he said I could stop it. Now I feel terrible - I can't sleep and I am more and more anxious (Sister has just been diagnosed with oesophageal Cancer which is not helping. Was I too ambitious in trying to come off them so soon? If you've had these medications what has been your experience. I'm grateful for any advice.
Posts.Title: Withdrawing from citalopram and diazepam.

Posts.Content: Hi Jamie. I've had 3 FEC which I coped well with, and 2 Tax so far which were harder but do-able. The pain I had was caused by the Filgrastin injections on days 3-7 of the cycle. The first cycle I was okay with paracetamol. The second cycle I had severe pain on one day & decided to phone the hospital if it didn't get better. The next day I had no pain at all! So it's very hard to predict what will happen. I have found that the biggest problem is fatigue which seems to be cumulative. I was still able to go to work for two of the three weeks of FEC, but with tax I'm simply too tired. There is also the infection risk to be considered. I also asked for some of the mouthwash as it helps against oral thrush. My nails have been okay so far (fingers crossed) and I use Body Shop almond oil hand cream. At night time I slap on as much foot and hand cream as I can & I've found that it helps. I'm sorry that I can't give you better advice. Like you, I was terrified of tax and now I'm just looking forward to the last one next Thursday and then it'll all be over. It seems like a terrible mountain to climb when you're facing it but the time does pass. I try a kind of self-hypnosis. & tell myself that I'll feel better tomorrow and generally I do. It's not wrong to feel sorry for yourself every now and again. I think we all do that, but I find it better to look to to future. My husband has booked a couple of days away in the Lake District in three weeks time to celebrate the end of chemo and that gives me something to look forward to. If you do have pain, the hospital should be able to help you. I haven't had to contact my BC nurse but I've always found the Oncology out patient advice line to be incredibly helpful and reassuring. I really do hope that you don't have a bad time on tax as I know that some people do suffer badly. I've just been very lucky so far. Wishing you all the best. Xx
Posts.Title: Worried about the Tac side of my Chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi everyone! The most useful items to me (apart from medicaments etc) were; my iPad, which was a lifesaver in keeping me occupied and connected, an ultrasonic toothbrush which was really gentle on my gums but kept my teeth clean, and non foaming toothpaste to stop me from gagging when I already felt nauseus. Xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute...

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. My husband and I are having a meeting tomorrow with a representative of our local Trust to address a couple of concerns we had about my treatment. One of them was the length of time it took to get the path report for the WLE. This was four weeks, and I know some other ladies who had to wait five weeks. The surgeon implied that it was because of a shortage of pathologists who deal specifically with breast tissue. I'd be interested in how long other people around the country have had to wait for WLE reports. Thanks for any info. Xxxx
Posts.Title: Time it takes for pathology report

Posts.Content: Just wanted to make it clear that we're not pursuing this for any monetary gain, nor are we looking for someone to "blame". We were very happy with the vast majority of the treatment I had and the absolute dedication and professionalism of the individual staff involved at different stages. The report that Stocksie mentioned makes very interesting reading - it highlights our main concerns very succinctly. Xxx
Posts.Title: Time it takes for pathology report

Posts.Content: Thanks Stocksie. We feel it is important to pursue this. I had added stress as one of the margins was ambiguous so they had to go back in again. Again I got an appt with the consultant for four weeks time. I really flipped - I was having problems with anxiety anyway and had been seeing the Clinical Psychologist at the Oncology Health Centre. The surgeon had advised us to complain to PALS  and we did. I then got a letter with an appt with the consultant for the following Thursday, which would have been two weeks after my second WLE. I went to see my GP on the Monday about another matter and he said, let me just check if your report is on the system. He came back with a piece of paper in his hand and he had underlined the words " no malignancy". I just sat and cried. The hospital would have been happy to let me stew until the Thursday. I just don't think that they understand the stress involved, and that even a few days can make such a difference. I'll check on that report, thanks! Xxx
Posts.Title: Time it takes for pathology report

Posts.Content: Hi Julie! It can depend on the chemo drug you're taking. I've had 3 FEC and found that after the anti emetics given by the hospital were finished I still had nausea. The oncologist recommended Cyclizine half an hour before meals ( 3 times a day) and Lanzoprozole twice a day. The Lanzoprozole reduces the amount of acid in your stomach. That has worked really well for me. I'm now on Docetaxal which is really hard and can make your finger nail go black. Check up on Internet for side effects of the chemo drugs and keep checking this site - it's brilliant for advice & support from people who are going through or have been through the same ordeal as you.. I do know how you feel about the isolation - the first time I had cancer I was living in Austria and I was utterly devastated by how isolated I was ( the after care was shockingly bad) I wish I'd had my iPad & McMillan online community then! Don't know if I've helped, but someone will come on to answer you and offer support. Hang on in there, girl! Xxx
Posts.Title: finger nails and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi! Like Moo46, I bought bandanas from Annabandana. They give fantastic service (sometimes items arrived the next day if I ordered early in the morning) and the prices are good with a wide range of head coverings in very nice patterns. I found the chiffon ones to be more comfortable as I thought the 100% cotton ones to be a bit scratchy. Check out their website! Xxx
Posts.Title: hats and scarves ?
